A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

"There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. "For the military industry of the world, you can't invent a better testing ground." Source: RT

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. UNESCO inscribed the ruins of Ashur (Photo on the right: UNESCO) as a World Heritage site in 2003. #TheNewSilkRoad #NewSilkRoadPics

Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July. A prominent power once dominated south Mesopotamia for centuries since the 2nd millennium BCE. It came to be known by the name of its capital: Babylon. The relics of this famous city of antiquity, situated south of Baghdad, Iraq, including walls, gates, palaces, and temples that bear the traces of the Babylonian civilization, now constitute a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contemporary of Babylon, the ancient city of Ashur in northern Mesopotamia was the first capital of the Assyrian empire from the 14th to 9th century BCE. It was once subjugated by the Babylonians before making a comeback during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. Ukraine has become a true "military innovation laboratory," particularly in the field of AI and drones, US Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy, Plans and Capabilities Mara Karlin said at a panel at the Ronald Reagan Institute on Wednesday. The valuable warfare insight coming from Ukraine is as important as the data harvested by the US military during its wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the senior Pentagon official noted. "There are things that you will learn not in a conflict, say through wargames or tabletop exercises, and then there are other things that one will inevitably learn when there's a war fight going on," she explained, while recollecting "how much innovation was happening" when US forces were in Iraq and Afghanistan and how they were "able to take certain things, put them onto the battlefield, figure out how to make certain shifts and apply them." Viewing Ukraine as a military "laboratory" of sorts is something that has been expressed not only by Kiev's overseas backers, but by the country's leadership as well. For instance, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has been advertised as an opportunity for Western arms makers by former Defense Minister Aleksey Reznikov. Kiev's Western supporters and their defense industry giants "can actually see if their weapons work, how efficiently they work and if they need to be upgraded," Reznikov told the Financial Times back in July.
